titleStmt.title: The declaration of Duke Hambleton at the head of his army, upon his joyning with Maj. Gen. Langdale in the north of England, concerning His most Gracious and Dread Soveraign Charkes [sic] King of Great Brittain. Likewise Major Generall Langdales propositions to the Lord Duke, concerning the Kings Majesty, and the Dukes answer thereunto. And the resolution of the Scots Army, with the manner of their march, their trumpets sounding, drums beating, and collours displaying with this motto, For Religion, King and Kingdom. Also the Duke of Buckinghams representation to the Lord Major of London, and his declaration, concerning the Kings Majesty.
titleStmt.author: Hamilton, James Hamilton, Duke of, 1606-1649.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 10 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for the generall satisfaction of all true subjects,

notesStmt.note: In fact only three letters, one signed on p.5: A.H. (i.e. James Hamilton), and two signed on p.6: G. Buckingham (i.e. George Villiers Buckingham).
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE DECLARATION OF Duke Hambleton At the head of His ARMY, UPON His joyning with Maj. Gen. Langdale in the North of ENGLAND, concerning His mo≈øt Gracious and Dread Soveraign CHARKES King of Great Brittain. LIKEWISE Major Generall Langdales Propo≈øitions to the Lord Duke, concerning the KINGS Maje≈øty, and the Dukes an≈øwer thereunto. AND The Re≈øolution of the Scots Army, with the manner of their march, their trumpets ≈øounding, Drums beating, and Collours di≈øplaying with this Motto, For Religion, King and Kingdom. Al≈øo, the Duke of Buckinghams Repre≈øentation to the Lord Major of London, and his Declaration, concerning the KINGS Maje≈øty
Printed for generall ≈øatisfaction of all true Subjects. 1648

div.head: The Declaration of Duke Hambleton, and his joyning with Major Generall LANGDALE.
div.p:
DUke Hamleton with his Army is marched to the confines of England, his Army numerous and impregnable to ours, their whole body of hor≈øe and foote con≈øi≈øting of about 12000 be≈øides 500 Curi≈øiers; their Motto in their colours are, For Religion, Crown and Kingdom. Their traine of Artiliry is ≈øaid to containe 27 peices of Ordnance, great and ≈ømall; but the greate≈øt part of them Scotch-ca≈øes (as they call them) each carriage and frame, carrying 7 or 8 ≈ømall peices. Their Army is now joyned with Major Generall Langdale, and Duke Hambleton hath declared to each Regiment throughout his Army, the cheif grounds and principles that invited them to this loyall engagement, intimating, that they were all bound and oblieged, both by their duty towards God, and their loyalty towards their King, to ri≈øe up as one man, for the pre≈øervation and
defence of Religion, Crown and Kingdoms, again≈øt all oppo≈øers what≈øoever.

Major Generall Langdale upon his uniting with Duke Hamleton, propounded ≈øeverall particulars touching their pr ‚Ä¢ ≈øent relaying, and ob≈øtructing the great worke in hand, in relation to their dread Soveraigne the King, but the Duke replyed, That the pre≈øent commotions and di≈øtempers in their native Kingdome, was the chiefe cau≈øe of ob≈øtructing the pro≈øecution of their de≈øigne, and engagement; but now they were re≈øolved to leave no waies of advantage unattempted.

Duke Hamleton hath further declared, that by the new ray≈øed Army, they will defend the Covenant, and the King, and u≈øe their utmo≈øt endeavours for the pre≈øervation of the Peace of both Kingdomes, and that they had no evill intents again≈øt the Kingdom of England, (as is fal≈øly ≈øugge≈øted) but to u≈øe their utmo≈øt endeavours for the reinve≈øting of the King, in his triumphant throne, ≈øetling of Religion, and the peace of the Kingdome, disbanding the Army and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of here≈øy.

Our forces hath had a late fight with Langdales the particulars whereof, I ≈øhall referre you to the enclo≈øed paper, a Copy whereof being ≈øent to the Honourable William L ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ thall E≈øquire Speaker of the Hou≈øe of Commons, by our Governour Sr. Arthur Hazelrig, which followeth in the≈øe words. viz.

body.p:
YOu have heard how Langdale retreated upon Major Generall Lamberts approaching, and
would not engage his Forces upon terms of advantage, re≈øolving to pre≈øerve his Body whole to joyne with the Scots, and upon his retreate to Carli≈øle, he ≈øent Collonell Tempe≈øt with Seaven or Eight hundred of his hor≈øe for to meet Collonel Grey, that was before that time kept up in Berwick by our Northumberland Hor≈øe, with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Major Sander≈øons two Troops; but upon Collonel Tempe≈øts comming into Northumberland, ours drew towards Newca≈øtle, and Collonel Grey with his Forces from Berwick joyned with Collonel Tempe≈øt about Alnwick: I ≈øent for Bi≈øhoprick Regiment, under Collonel Wren, to come into Northumberland to joyne with Collonel Fenwick (who commanded the Northumberland new ray≈øed Regiment) and Major Sander≈øon, I al≈øo mounted about one hundred of my foot as dragoons, and ≈øent them to them: I writ al≈øo to Major General Lambert, letting him under≈øtand that the Enemy was joyned, and intreated him to ≈øend ≈øome a≈ø≈øi≈øtance immediatly to our forces.

Upon Fryday la≈øt Col Lilburne with three troops of hor≈øe, came to them to Collerton, and that Evening they marched towards the Enemy that lay at E≈ølington, & Whittingham, and all along Cocquet water; having marched all night, the next morning they fell into their quarters, the Enemy having no Scouts out, and they fell ≈øo clo≈øe in from town to town for about 7 miles, that they ≈øuffered the enemy to take no Alarum: there are taken mo≈øt of the con≈øiderable gentlemen of Northumberland & Bi≈øhprick
that were the very fir≈øt beginners of this War, and incouragers of the Scots to come into England, and at lea≈øt three hundred private Souldiers, and betweene five and ≈øix hundred Hor≈øes, aod good ≈øtore of Armes, without the lo≈ø≈øe of one man of either ≈øide.

I have inclo≈øed a letter ≈øent to me from Collonel Lilburne, in which you will ≈øee the enemies intention, and have cau≈øe to give God the greater prai≈øe, that when the enemy thought nor to fight, that God was plea≈øed then to give them up into our hands, without ≈øtriking a ≈øtroke, and that to their everla≈øting ≈øhame.

I have al≈øo ≈øent you a li≈øt of the Commanders and Gentlemen that are taken, I be≈øeech you do not apprehend that the worke in the North is done, God having be≈øtowed this great mercy upon us; for be a≈ø≈øured the Scots are come very neare the Borders, and Langdale is joyned with them, and their numbers will be farre too great for what we are able to with≈øtand in the≈øe parts, only to God nothing is impo≈ø≈øible.

Some of the foot Souldiers of this Garri≈øon, and ≈øome of ovr new ray≈øed hor≈øe ran away to the enemy, and we have taken divers of them, and we intend to try them by a Coun≈øell of War, unle≈ø≈øe you plea≈øe to di≈øpo≈øe otherwi≈øe of them; if ≈øo, we de≈øire we may ≈øpeedily know your plea≈øure; if not they will be ≈øuddanly knit up: Col. Grey compounded at Gold≈ømiths Hall and did take the Covenant, and ≈øo have ≈øome others, and there is not a man in the
North of England, that hath done you more mi≈øcheif then Collonel Grey: I ≈øhall take the be≈øt care I can to keep them ≈øafe in Tinmouth-Ca≈øtle, till I know what your commands are, and you have now in cu≈øtody your chiefe≈øt enemies in Northumberland and Bi≈øhoprick, for the begining of ‚Ä¢ his new Warre in the Nothern parts, and the taking of Barwick.

div.head: The Declaration of the Duke of Buckingham, and the Earles of Holland and Peterborrough, concerning their taking up of Armes for the King.
div.p:
WEE do here declare that we do take up arms for the King and Parliament, Religion, and the known Laws and peace of all his Maje≈øties Kingdoms: profe≈ø≈øing before Almighty God, that we have no other de≈øigne in this undertaking; but to ≈øee this well, and truely e≈øtabli≈øhed, and will with readines and joy lay them down when≈øoever God ≈øhall give us the injoyment of ≈øuch a ble≈ø≈øing, profe≈ø≈øing that what≈øoever may be our ≈øucce≈ø≈øe and pro≈øperity in this good cau≈øe, we ≈øhall not ≈øay by way of menace to the Parliament, that we will u≈øe the power God hath put into our hands; but ≈øhall ble≈ø≈øe God that he hath made us the in≈øtruments to ≈øerve the King, the Parliament and Kingdom in the way of peace, in a ju≈øt and equall compo≈øure between them: and wee hope the City and the Kingdom, will well weigh and con≈øider whether they may not more rea≈øonably
and con≈øcionably joyne with us in the≈øe pious and peaceable re≈øolutions. This we thought fit both to de≈øire and to declare that the di≈øcour≈øes that may be ray≈øed upon our actions, may not have power to abu≈øe the Kingdom, as if we did only move in a way to ≈øet up his Maje≈øty in a tyrannicall power, rather then in his ju≈øt Regall Government, the which hath been alwaies found in this Nation, very well con≈øi≈øtant with the due rights and freedoms of Parliament, the which do here mo≈øt faithfully prote≈øt the endeavouring a pre≈øervation of, and call God to witne≈ø≈øe of our ≈øincerity in this intention.

div.head: To the Lord Major, Aldermen, and Commons of the City in Common-Councell A≈ø≈øembled.
div.p: HAving a long time beheld the ≈øad calamities & mi≈øeries of the≈øe Kingdoms, & finding no other means for redre≈ø≈øe, we are forced into this undertaking, which we de≈øire may be rightly under≈øtood of all wel-affected, e≈øpecially of this City, who≈øe actions & endevours do ≈øufficiently evidence their good affections. To this end we have enclo≈øed a breife account of our intentions, which we hope may give ≈øatisfaction both to you, and the whole Kingdom, who≈øe a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, (with Gods ble≈ø≈øing) we de≈øire no farther, then our de≈øigns are reall for the good & happynes both of the King Parliament, and Kingdom, according to our Covenant.

closer.signed:
Your humble ≈øervants,
G. BUCKINGHAM.
HOLLAND.
PETERBORROUGH
